private_information: Available actions: paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted. Actions accept three or four object arguments as described in the overall specification.
Action schema summary: paltry requires hand X, cats Y, texture Z, vase X Y, next Y Z. Effects: add next X Z and delete vase X Y.
sip requires hand X, cats Y, texture Z, next X Z, next Y Z. Effects: add vase X Y and delete next X Z.
clip requires hand X, sneeze Y, texture Z, next Y Z, next X Z. Effects: add vase X Y and delete next X Z.
wretched requires sneeze X, texture Y, texture Z, stupendous W, next X Y, collect Y W, collect Z W. Effects: add next X Z and delete next X Y.
memory requires cats X, spring Y, spring Z, next X Y. Effects: add next X Z and delete next X Y.
tightfisted requires hand X, sneeze Y, texture Z, next Y Z, vase X Y. Effects: add next X Z and delete vase X Y.
player.goal: Provide a detailed structured report enumerating every action's preconditions and effects and identifying which object roles appear in each action. Do not produce final PDDL. Focus on clear formalization of schemas and on pointing out ambiguous names or overlapping predicates.

private_information: Initial facts variant A: cats object_0, cats object_1, collect object_10 object_3, collect object_11 object_3, collect object_6 object_2, collect object_7 object_2, collect object_8 object_2, collect object_9 object_3, hand object_12, hand object_13, hand object_14, next object_0 object_9, next object_1 object_6, next object_12 object_11, next object_13 object_8, next object_14 object_8, next object_4 object_7, next object_5 object_10, sneeze object_4, sneeze object_5, spring object_6, spring object_9, stupendous object_2, stupendous object_3, texture object_10, texture object_11, texture object_6, texture object_7, texture object_8, texture object_9.
Goal variant A: next object_12 object_6, next object_13 object_10, next object_14 object_11.

Initial facts variant B: cats object_0, cats object_1, collect object_10 object_3, collect object_11 object_3, collect object_6 object_2, collect object_7 object_2, collect object_8 object_2, collect object_9 object_3, hand object_12, hand object_13, hand object_14, next object_0 object_6, next object_1 object_9, next object_12 object_11, next object_13 object_6, next object_14 object_8, next object_4 object_7, next object_5 object_10, sneeze object_4, sneeze object_5, spring object_6, spring object_9, stupendous object_2, stupendous object_3, texture object_10, texture object_11, texture object_6, texture object_7, texture object_8, texture object_9.
Goal variant B: next object_12 object_10, next object_13 object_10, next object_14 object_9.
analyst.goal: Validate which initial facts enable which actions, enumerate reachable intermediate next predicates that serve as subgoals, and produce an ordering of action types required to reach the stated goals. Do not emit final PDDL. Emphasize dependencies among predicates and any conflicting deletes and adds.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate reports from the other agents and produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem pair that faithfully model the actions, the chosen initial facts, and the desired goal. The PDDL should be compatible with the FastDownward planner and clearly separate agent-level roles if needed.

public_information: Objects are named object_0 through object_14 with various roles used by the actions.
Predicates used in the domain include hand, cats, texture, vase, next, collect, sneeze, spring, stupendous.
Actions in the domain are paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, and tightfisted. Each action has preconditions and effects that manipulate next and vase predicates among others.
There are two alternative initial goal scenarios referenced as variant A and variant B. The orchestrator must select the correct initial facts set when building the problem instance.

analysis.system_prompt: You are the player agent responsible for formalizing action schemas. Using your private information enumerate each action with a formal listing of named parameters, explicit positive preconditions, explicit delete effects, and add effects. Highlight any cases where predicates or object roles overlap or are ambiguous. Do not produce PDDL domain or problem files. Produce a concise structured report labeled player_report.

review.system_prompt: You are the analyst agent responsible for initial state and goal analysis. Using your private information, list the initial facts for the chosen scenario, identify reachable intermediate facts that are required to achieve the goal, and provide an ordering of action types that can achieve the goal given the action schemas. Point out actions that delete needed facts and propose mitigations. Do not produce PDDL domain or problem files. Produce a concise structured report labeled analyst_report.

pddl.system_prompt: You are the orchestrator. Integrate the structured reports player_report and analyst_report into a single coherent PDDL domain and a single coherent PDDL problem. The resulting PDDL must be directly compatible with the FastDownward planner. Provide a domain file and a problem file. Enclose the domain between <domain> and </domain> tags and enclose the problem between <problem> and </problem> tags. Keep action names, predicate names, and object names consistent and avoid renaming that would confuse matching between domain and problem. Preserve distinctions when actions have overlapping effects and make agent-level roles explicit if necessary. The outputs must implement the preconditions and effects reported by the other agents and model the chosen initial facts and goal conditions. The domain should use STRIPS style predicates and include typing only if it simplifies the model.
